intro: Commiphora berberidifolia, commonly known as the African myrrh, is a small evergreen shrub native to the arid regions of southern Africa. It belongs to the Burseraceae family, which includes frankincense and myrrh trees. The plant is characterized by its dense, leathery leaves and produces a resinous sap that has been historically used in traditional medicine. Its botanical features include small, white or yellowish flowers that bloom in spring, followed by small, red berries. The plant thrives in well-drained soils and is adapted to withstand drought conditions.
